name: Brayden Engelhard
comment info: This graph effectively highlights the significant rise in summer temperatures in Las Vegas since 1950, with overnight lows increasing by an alarming 11°F and daily highs by 2°F. It does a great job of visually emphasizing the disparity in temperature trends, drawing attention to the faster warming of nights. This pattern likely points to urbanization and the heat island effect as key contributors. However, the graph could benefit from additional context, such as annotations on population growth or comparative data from similar cities, to deepen understanding of the underlying causes. Despite this, the clear presentation of data trends makes it a strong tool for sparking conversation about the urgent need for sustainable urban planning and climate resilience.

comment info: Something that I noticed was that the graph’s ups and downs in both high and low temperatures seem to look very similar to the solar flare patterns in the last 60-75 years. Whenever there was a bit of a dip in the temperature, there was lower solar activity. Whenever there was a high in solar activity, the temperature was higher. Another thing that I noticed was the sun is going through a little stage where it is burning out a lot of energy, causing more solar flares than usual. That is why there are so many more counts of northern lights, not so far in the north at more unusual times as well. This activity is going to peak in the summer of 2025, and then cool off according to studies done in San Diego State University. I wonder if there is less “global warming” than we think and we might be ignoring the sun itself.

name: Tristan Hirt
comment info:
-All Bets Are Off, The Thermastat is On.-
By viewing the graph, one can notice the rising daily temperatures. Not necesarily during the day, as Vegas has closely averaged 105*F since the 60's with only a slight daytime temperature increase. The real issue however is the nightly temperatures, as they have increased from 70*F in the 60's to well over 80 today. with that nightly increase, the 24-hour total would be much higher today than it was sixty years ago.
How much hotter will the nights become until daytime temperatures increase as well, and when daytime averages start increasing will the affect on the nightly temperatures increase more dramatically than before- leading to exponential heat?
Las Vegas isn't the only city in the United States, as an Urban resident, will the rising temperatures mean more danger for people in cities everywhere? How will people relocate, can they relocate?

Las Vegas Nights Are Heating Up: Alarming Rise in Overnight Temperatures Risks Public Health

name: Tristan Hirt
comment info:
-All Bets Are Off, The Thermastat is On.-
By viewing the graph, one can notice the rising daily temperatures. Not necesarily during the day, as Vegas has closely averaged 105*F since the 60's with only a slight daytime temperature increase. The real issue however is the nightly temperatures, as they have increased from 70*F in the 60's to well over 80 today. with that nightly increase, the 24-hour total would be much higher today than it was sixty years ago.
How much hotter will the nights become until daytime temperatures increase as well, and when daytime averages start increasing will the affect on the nightly temperatures increase more dramatically than before- leading to exponential heat?
Las Vegas isn't the only city in the United States, as an Urban resident, will the rising temperatures mean more danger for people in cities everywhere? How will people relocate, can they relocate?

I also wonder what this graph would look like in a different part of America. The daily high could have climbed more over time, and the overnight lows would have been more stable. This graph relates to my community because the world is getting hotter, and global warming should be observed. I may not live in Las Vegas, but it's important to compare the rising temperatures across the globe to assess accurately how dangerous global warming is to our planet. Title: "Not so cool summer nights in Vegas"

name: Daniel Vasquez
comment info:
1. (Observations) The graph shows the increase of daily summer high and overnight low summer temperatures in Las Vegas since 1950. For the overnight lows, there was a slow and steady rise between 1950 and 1980 until it started to spike significantly by the year 2000. From then on, it continued to increase for the next 20 years, with a total of +11 F from 1950-2020. The daily highs remained mostly constant, with a brief but noticeable dip sometime in the 1980s. From then on, It finally had an increase of +2 F from 1950-2020. Ultimately, the temperature rose in both areas and is likely to follow an upward trend into the 2020s. 

2. (What do you wonder?) I wonder what caused a brief decrease for both daily high and overnight low temperatures as the timeline approaches the 1980s. Did a major event or political change occur during this period? In addition, have the states or areas surrounding Las Vegas experience similar trends in temperature as a result of climate change? 

3. (Relation to Community) The steady increase in overnight low summer temperatures is a call to the ongoing trends of climate change, which affects a vast amount of communities worldwide, which brings health and environmental implications, such as the risk of heat-related illnesses, wildfires, and quality of life. As such, it is important to notice the changes in temperatures over time and address them. 

4. (Headline) Las Vegas Nights Ablaze: Daily Temperatures on the High Roller

The temperatures increase so much that they're even above 100 degrees F in the daily highs, which can be dangerous for humans, with nearly 110 degrees F being depicted in the graph, and slightly above 80 degrees F for overnight lows, which is still not normal at all. 
What do I wonder?: I wonder why they didn't record the temperature changes from before the 1950s as well. Were the temperatures considered somewhat normal and harmless before the 1950s? Is it too late to fix the damages humans have done, causing these threatening soars of heat? 
How does this relate to me and my community?: This graph doesn't only relate to Las Vegas, this graph relates to the entire world. Furthermore, my state, my county, and my town is affected by these harmful rises in temperatures. If temperatures have gotten this bad in Las Vegas, it only takes a few years until New Jersey reaches this detrimental point also. It is even felt in the summers of my own town recently, these recent summers have felt like the hottest since I've lived here. It's only about time until New Jersey becomes like Las Vegas, Nevada. 

HEADLINE: Can You Handle the Heat?: And, We Don't Just Mean in the Casinos
